Focus on one thing at a time. You can have it all in life, but not all at once.  Working on a start-up that is our dream can be an emotional burden for us in the early days. But doing three jobs at a time, rarely you will succeed at any of them. You need to put all of your energy towards it -- whatever it is you want to achieve the most in life. You have to keep your eyes on the big picture. Extra few hundred dollars might help you make ends meet but the opportunity cost might actually be worth thousands.

Don't worry if you feel like it's hard to make new friends. Don't worry if you feel like you haven't met anyone who's like you and you feel absolutely happy to be around. Just be yourself and be as open as you can. Never stop going to events or attend Meet Ups of your interests and do your thing. The people who are compatible with you will find their ways to you. They will instantly be attracted to you as much as you are attracted to them.

The innumerous nights spent toiling away, laughing wildly, doubting myself, cursing the system, and somehow finishing my undergraduate thesis and, eventually, my degree. From the first day, when my father reminded me of the reason he was parting ways with me while I wanted to go back with him, to the day I found myself all teary at having to bid adieu to this beautiful institute that became my home, the time spent at IIT Indore is well engraved in my heart. Some worthwhile mentions are my time spent on the football field, my assignments in the computer lab, my time spent in quizzing, and the time when I directed and acted in a drama based on the story Panch Parmeshwar.

I would take along the amazing Aditya, Sanchit and Punit. Aditya finds a seat in my hatchback for the intellect and level-headedness he carries. Lest I forget, he also cracks high-level jokes much like me which further strengthens his case. Sanchit gets a seat owing to his humorous demeanour. Furthermore, he can throw coconuts on anyone who tries to dupe us during our trip, thereby, enhancing the security of our journey together. Lastly, Punit manages a seat in my car because of his thirst for adventure. He is willing to push the boundaries of his comfort zone when it comes to new experiences and this shall make our trip one of the most amazing ever.

The seventh semester, during which I completed my B.Tech project, was the most fun due to the freedom I could exercise. I decided what I studied, what research direction I pursued, and what time I woke up at. Having already secured a nice job offer might have added to the fun I had during that time.

The institute has made me independent in every sense of the word. In stark contrast to four years ago, when I struggled to make decisions for myself, I was forced to decide on my technical interests, my job profile, and a lot else during college, matters on which my family had limited input to provide. From being driven by my family, I am now in a position to drive my family ahead, and this I owe to the institute.
I would increase the frequency of e-vehicles plying on our campus. On a side note, I might hire some more professors in the field of machine learning and theoretical computer science.
I wish to pursue a career in research or product development.

“I've learned one thing, and that's to quit worrying about stupid things. You have four years to be irresponsible here, relax. Work is for people with jobs. You'll never remember class time, but you'll remember the time you wasted hanging out with your friends. So stay out late. Go out with your friends on a Tuesday when you have a paper due on Wednesday. Spend money you don't have. Drink 'til sunrise. The work never ends, but college does...” 
― Tom Petty
